meanings.definition: (verb) to become limp or drooping, as a dying plant
meanings.sent1: After a long day in the sun, the flowers began to wilt in the heat.
meanings.sent2: Without water, the leaves of the plant will wilt and eventually die.
meanings.sent3: The poor plant started to wilt like a sad puppy when it wasn't watered.
meanings.sent4: Her enthusiasm wilted like a flower without sunlight as the project dragged on.
meanings.sent5: The once vibrant petals began to wilt, their colors fading away.

meanings.sent1: His confidence started to wilt after facing repeated failures.
meanings.sent2: The team's spirit began to wilt as they fell behind in the game.
meanings.sent3: The balloon wilted with disappointment when it didn't win the race.
meanings.sent4: Her determination wilted under the pressure of the upcoming exam.
meanings.sent5: The soldier's resolve wilted in the face of overwhelming odds.

meanings.definition: (noun) the act of wilting or the state of being wilted
meanings.sent1: The wilt of the flowers was a clear sign they needed more water.
meanings.sent2: She noticed the wilt of the leaves and immediately watered the plant.
meanings.sent3: The wilt of the plant made it look like it was begging for a drink.
meanings.sent4: The garden showed signs of wilt after days of scorching heat.
meanings.sent5: The farmer recognized the wilt of the crops and knew it was time to irrigate.
